revision.text:
{{For|the compensatory growth of organs|Compensatory growth (organ)}}
[[File:Compensatory Growth.jpg|thumb|400px|Representation of compensatory growth]]
'''Compensatory growth''', known as '''catch-up growth''' and '''compensatory gain''', is an accelerated growth of an organism following a period of slowed development, particularly as a result of [[nutrient]] deprivation.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002">{{cite book|author1=David E. Gerrard|author2=Alan L. Grant|title=Principles of Animal Growth and Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oZbbxMdGJBEC&pg=PA204|accessdate=5 June 2011|date=September 2002|publisher=Kendall Hunt|isbn=978-0-7872-9147-1|pages=204–208}}</ref><ref name="LawrenceFowler2002">{{cite book|author1=Tony Leonard John Lawrence|author2=V. R. Fowler|title=Growth of farm animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6YycK_V2fJQC&pg=PA229|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=November 2002|publisher=CABI|isbn=978-0-85199-484-0|pages=229–254}}</ref> The growth may be with respect to weight or length (or height in humans).<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="CG9FullGuideline"/><ref name="pediatrics"/><ref name="Estrogen production and action"/><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen"/><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term"/><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth"/> For example, oftentimes the body weights of animals who experience nutritional restriction will over time become similar to those of animals who did not experience such stress.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> It is possible for high compensatory growth rates to result in overcompensation, where the organism exceeds normal weight and often has excessive fat deposition.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture">{{cite book|title=fundamentals of modern agriculture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EqkOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA279|accessdate=6 June 2011|publisher=Taylor & Francis|pages=279–280|id=GGKEY:BP74C846RC5}}</ref>
An organism can recover to normal weight without additional time.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Sometimes when the nutrient restriction is severe, the growth period is extended to reach the normal weight.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> If the nutrient restriction is severe enough, the organism may have permanent [[stunted growth]] where it does not ever reach normal weight.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Usually in animals, complete recovery from [[carbohydrate]] and [[protein]] restriction occurs.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/>
Compensatory growth has been observed in a number of organisms including [[human]]s,<ref name="CG9FullGuideline"/><ref name="pediatrics"/><ref name="Estrogen production and action"/><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen"/><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term"/><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth"/> other species of [[mammal]]s,<ref name=Wilson>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilson | first1 = P. | last2 = Osbourn | first2 = D. | title = Compensatory growth after undernutrition in mammals and birds | journal = Biological Reviews of the Cambridge Philosophical Society | volume = 35 | pages = 324–363 | year = 1960 | pmid = 13785698 }}</ref> [[bird]]s,<ref name=Wilson/> [[reptile]]s,<ref name=Radder>{{Cite journal | last1 = Radder | first1 = R. S. | last2 = Warner | first2 = D. A. | last3 = Shine | first3 = R. | title = Compensating for a bad start: Catch-up growth in juvenile lizards (Amphibolurus muricatus, agamidae) | doi = 10.1002/jez.403 | journal = Journal of Experimental Zoology Part A: Ecological Genetics and Physiology | volume = 307A | issue = 9 | pages = 500–508 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17620280 }}</ref> [[fish]],<ref name="Diana2004">{{cite book|author=James S. Diana|title=Biology and ecology of fishes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yMzwAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=2004|publisher=Biological Sciences Press, a Division of Cooper Pub. Group|isbn=978-1-884125-98-0|page=66}}</ref><ref name="Turkmen et al., 2012">{{cite journal|last1=Turkmen|first1=Serhat|title=Compensatory growth response of European sea bass (Dicentrarchus labrax L.) under cycled starvation and restricted feeding rate|journal=Aquaculture Research|date=2012|issue=43|pages=1643–1650}}</ref> [[plant]]s (especially [[grass]]es and young tree [[seedling]]s and [[sapling]]s),<ref name="OrcuttNilsen2000">{{cite book|author1=David M. Orcutt|author2=Erik T. Nilsen|title=The Physiology of Plants Under Stress: Soil and biotic factors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zDIOVVEQEfcC&pg=PA277|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=2000|publisher=John Wiley and Sons|isbn=978-0-471-17008-2|pages=277–278}}</ref> [[fungi]],<ref name=Bretherton>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bretherton | first1 = S. | last2 = Tordoff | first2 = G. M. | last3 = Jones | first3 = T. H. | last4 = Boddy | first4 = L. | title = Compensatory growth of Phanerochaete velutina mycelial systems grazed by Folsomia candida (Collembola) | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-6941.2006.00149.x | journal = FEMS Microbiology Ecology | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–40 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16958906 }}</ref> [[microbe]]s,<ref name=Mikola>{{citation |author=Mikola J. |author2=H. Setala |last-author-amp=yes |year=1998 |title=No evidence of tropic cascades in an experimental microbial-based food web |journal=Ecology |volume=79 |pages=153–164 |doi=10.2307/176871}}</ref> and [[Eastern Forktail|damselflies]].<ref name=Dmitriew>{{Cite journal | last1 = Dmitriew | first1 = C. | last2 = Rowe | first2 = L. | doi = 10.1007/s00442-004-1712-2 | title = Resource limitation, predation risk and compensatory growth in a damselfly | journal = Oecologia | volume = 142 | issue = 1 | pages = 150–154 | year = 2004 | pmid = 15372227 }}</ref>
==History== In 1911, Hans Aron performed the earliest study of growth after periods of undernourishment.<ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996">{{cite book|author1=C. J. K. Henry|author2=Stanley J. Ulijaszek|title=Long-term consequences of early environment: growth, development, and the lifespan developmental perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=66JbrqPjINgC&pg=PA128|accessdate=6 June 2011|year=1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-47108-4|pages=124–138}}</ref> He underfed a dog and found that it still had the capacity to rapidly gain weight, though it did not reach the final weight of a dog that was fed normally.<ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name=Aron>{{cite journal|last=Aron|first=H.|year=1911 |title=Nutrition and growth|journal=Philippine Journal of Sciences, Section B (Medical Science) |volume=6|pages=1–52}}</ref> In 1915, Osborne and Mendel were the first to demonstrate that rats fed after growth restriction had an accelerated growth rate.<ref name=Wilson/><ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name=Osborne>{{cite journal|last1= Osborne|first1=T.B.|last2= Mendel |first2=L. B.|year=1915 |title=The resumption of growth after long continued failure to grow|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=23|pages=439–454}}</ref> In 1945, Brody developed the idea of “homoestasis of growth” in the book ''Bioenergetics and Growth''.<ref name=Wilson/><ref name="HenryUlijaszek1996"/><ref name="Brody">{{cite book|author=S. Brody |title= Bioenergetics and Growth|year=1945|publisher= Reinhold }}</ref> In 1955, Verle Bohman was the first to use the term “compensatory growth” in an article pertaining to [[beef cattle]].<ref name=Wilson/><ref name=Bohman>{{cite journal |last=Bohman |first=V. R. |year=1955 |title= Compensatory Growth of Beef Cattle: The Effect of Hay Maturity |journal= Journal of Animal Science |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages= 249–255 }}</ref>
==Mechanism== In animals, [[Homeostasis|homeostatic]] and [[Homeorhesis|homeorhetic]] processes are involved in the abnormally high growth rates.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> Homeostatic processes usually affect compensatory growth in the short term, whereas homeorhetic processes usually have a long-term effect.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/>
The exact biological mechanisms for compensatory growth are poorly understood, though it is clear that in some animals the [[endocrine system]] is involved in the [[metabolism]] and nutrient partitioning in the tissues.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="Scanes2003">{{cite book|author=C. G. Scanes|title=Biology of growth of domestic animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R4Qau0BMeoIC&pg=PA352|accessdate=6 June 2011|date=24 April 2003|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-8138-2906-7|page=352}}</ref> First, during nutrient starvation, a reduction of [[Basal animal metabolic rate|basal metabolism]] takes place.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/><ref name="Scanes2003"/> The gut tissues are the first tissues to be reduced in weight and activity.<ref name="Scanes2003"/> Then, during the realimentation (re-feeding) phase, an increase in feeding enables more dietary protein and energy to be contributed for tissue growth instead of basal metabolism.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/> The gut tissues are the first to increase in weight, followed by muscle tissue and finally adipose tissue.<ref name="Scanes2003"/>
==Studies of growth in anorexic human patients== [[Anorexia nervosa]] can have serious implications if its duration and severity are significant and if onset occurs before the completion of growth, pubertal maturation or prior to attaining peak bone mass.<ref name="medical">{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1099-0968(200003)8:2<170::AID-ERV338>3.0.CO;2-Y|title=Medical complications of anorexia nervosa in children and young adolescents|year=2000|last1=Nicholls|first1=Dasha|last2=Stanhope|first2=Richard|journal=European Eating Disorders Review|volume=8|issue=2|pages=170–180}} </ref> Both height gain and pubertal development are dependent on the release of growth hormone and gonadotrophins (LH and FSH) from the pituitary gland. Suppression of gonadotropins in patients with anorexia nervosa has been frequently documented.<ref name="medical"/> In some cases, especially where onset is pre-pubertal, physical consequences such as stunted growth and pubertal delay are usually fully reversible.<ref name="CG9FullGuideline">{{cite journal|journal=National Collaborating Centre for Mental Health|year=2004 |title=Core interventions in the treatment and management of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa and related eating disorders |url=http://www.nice.org.uk/nicemedia/pdf/CG9FullGuideline.pdf}}</ref> Height potential is normally preserved if the duration and severity of anorexia nervosa are not significant and/or if the illness is accompanied with delayed bone age (especially prior to a bone age of approximately 15 years), as hypogonadism may negate the deleterious effects of undernutrition on stature by allowing for a longer duration of growth compared to controls.<ref name="pediatrics">{{Cite journal | last1 = Prabhakaran | first1 = R. | last2 = Misra | first2 = M. | last3 = Miller | first3 = K. K. | last4 = Kruczek | first4 = K. | last5 = Sundaralingam | first5 = S. | last6 = Herzog | first6 = D. B. | last7 = Katzman | first7 = D. K. | last8 = Klibanski | first8 = A. | doi = 10.1542/peds.2007-2820 | title = Determinants of Height in Adolescent Girls with Anorexia Nervosa | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 121 | issue = 6 | pages = e1517–e1523 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18519455 | pmc = }}</ref> In such cases, appropriate early treatment can preserve height potential and may even help to increase it in some post-anorexic subjects due to the aforementioned reasons in addition to factors such as long-term reduced estrogen-producing [[adipose tissue]] levels compared to premorbid levels.<ref name="Estrogen production and action">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nelson LR, Bulun SE |title=Estrogen production and action |journal=J. Am. Acad. Dermatol. |volume=45 |issue=3 Suppl |pages=S116–24 |year=2001 |pmid=11511861 |doi= 10.1067/mjd.2001.117432}}</ref><ref name="The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen">{{cite journal |author=Carter, Shea L.|title=The genetic basis of human height : the role of estrogen |year=2008 |url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/28390/}}</ref><ref name="Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term">{{cite web|work=Reuters|date=2008-06-06 |title=Anorexia nervosa may not stunt growth, short term |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/06/06/us-anorexia-nervosa-idUSCOL66234120080606}}</ref><ref name="Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth">{{cite journal | pmid = 3943254 | volume=25 | title=Effect of anorexia nervosa on linear growth | journal=Clin Pediatr (Phila) | pages=7–12 | last1 = Pfeiffer | first1 = RJ | last2 = Lucas | first2 = AR | last3 = Ilstrup | first3 = DM}}</ref>
==Factors affecting compensatory growth== In 1960, Wilson and Osborne outlined six factors that could affect compensatory growth in a review article.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/><ref name=Wilson/> The importance of each, some, or all of these factors is not well understood.<ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/> These factors are as follows:<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/><ref name="fundamentals of modern agriculture"/><ref name=Wilson/> * The nature of the restricted diet * The degree of severity of undernutrition * The duration of the period of undernutrition * The stage of development at the commencement of undernutrition * The relative rate of maturity of the species * The pattern of re-alimenation
Animal factors that can affect compensatory growth may include the maturity level and fat proportion of the animal at the time of nutrient deprivation, the genotype, the gender, and the metabolic changes.<ref name="LawrenceFowler2002"/> The stage of development of the animal when the nutrient restriction occurs greatly affects its body composition.<ref name="GerrardGrant2002"/>
==See also== *[[Starvation]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Biology]]

revision.comment: /* The Process: Convergent Evolution and Examples of Despeciation */form => from
revision.text:
{{short description|The loss of a unique species of animal due to its combining with another previously distinct species}} '''Despeciation''' is the loss of a unique species of animal due to its combining with another previously distinct species.{{cite web|title=Despeciation|url=http://www.medilexicon.com/medicaldictionary.php?t=24093|work=Stedman's Medical Dictionary|accessdate=28 December 2012}} It is the opposite of [[Speciation]] and is much more rare. It is similar to extinction in that there is a loss of a unique [[species]] but without the associated loss of a biological lineage. Despeciation has been noted in species of butterflies, sunflowers, mosquitoes, fish, wolves, and even humans.{{Cite web|url=https://cosmosmagazine.com/biology/two-become-one-raven-species-reverse-darwin-s-tree|title=Two become one: raven species reverse Darwin's tree {{!}} Cosmos|website=cosmosmagazine.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}} == The Process: Convergent Evolution and Examples of Despeciation == A prime example of despeciation is convergent evolution due to the fact that it causes two species that live in same environment to become the same due to the similar functions and behaviors that it must partake in to survive in that habitat. Common examples of convergent evolution are [[Müllerian mimicry|Mullerian]] and [[Batesian mimicry|Batesian]] mimicry. Batesian mimicry is when one species that is harmless mimics a more threatening, or intimidating, species as to prevent it from being killed. Mullerian mimicry is when two organisms mimic each other as to prevent either species from being killed by predators.{{Cite web|url=http://www.zo.utexas.edu/courses/THOC/Convergence.html|title=Convergent Evolution|website=www.zo.utexas.edu|access-date=2018-11-06}} Despeciation also occurs when two diverged species begin to interact in the same region. Ravens provide a prime example of this. Holarctic Ravens and Californian Ravens had been two separate species for 1.5 million years until tens of thousands of years ago when their regions overlapped and they began to merge into a new species. This new raven species contains genes coming from both the Holarctic and Californian Raven. This was possible because they occupy the same area of the Western United States.{{Cite web|url=https://cosmosmagazine.com/biology/two-become-one-raven-species-reverse-darwin-s-tree|title=Two become one: raven species reverse Darwin's tree {{!}} Cosmos|website=cosmosmagazine.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}} ==Example of three-spined sticklebacks== [[Image:Gasterosteus aculeatus.jpg|thumb|left|The [[three-spined stickleback]] (''Gasterosteus aculeatus'')]] Another possible cause for despeciation is increased gene flow and hybridization due to changes in the environment. One of these changes could include the loss of essential nourishment resources for each individual species. For example, Taylor et al.'s genetic analysis of [[three-spined stickleback]]s across six lakes in southwestern [[British Columbia]] found two distinct species in 1977 and 1988 but only one combined species in data from 1997, 2000, and 2002. The new species is a hybrid and shows an intermediate form of the parental genotype. They concluded that external factors had imperiled the living conditions of the two species, thus eliminating the evolutionary specializations that had kept them unique.{{Cite journal|last=TAYLOR|first=E. B.|last2=BOUGHMAN|first2=J. W.|last3=GROENENBOOM|first3=M.|last4=SNIATYNSKI|first4=M.|last5=SCHLUTER|first5=D.|last6=GOW|first6=J. L.|date=2005-11-30|title=Speciation in reverse: morphological and genetic evidence of the collapse of a three-spined stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus) species pair|journal=Molecular Ecology|language=en|volume=15|issue=2|pages=343–355|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294x.2005.02794.x|pmid=16448405|issn=0962-1083}}
== How Does This Affect Us? == Other common examples of despeciation pertain to ''Homo sapiens''. ''Homo sapiens'' once were two lineages, Neanderthals and Denisovans. However, due to common ecological niches, common ancestry, similar environment, and interbreeding, they merged into one species....... {{Cite news|url=https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/what-is-despeciation.html|title=What Is Despeciation?|work=WorldAtlas|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Extinction |state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Evolution]] [[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Speciation]]

revision.comment: fixing wikilinks and some minor changes in grammar
revision.text:
'''Unconventional protein secretion''' (known as ER/Golgi-independent protein secretion or nonclassical protein export<ref name="bla3">{{cite journal|last=Backhaus|first=R|author2=Zehe, C |author3=Wegehingel, S |author4=Kehlenbach, A |author5=Schwappach, B |author6= Nickel, W |title=Unconventional protein secretion: membrane translocation of FGF-2 does not require protein unfolding.|journal=Journal of Cell Science|date=Apr 1, 2004|volume=117|issue=Pt 9|pages=1727–36|pmid=15075234|doi=10.1242/jcs.01027}}</ref> ) represents a manner in which the proteins are delivered to the surface of [[plasma membrane]] or [[extracellular matrix]] independent of the [[Endoplasmic reticulum]] or [[Golgi apparatus]].<ref name="bla1"/> This includes [[cytokines]] and [[mitogens]] with crucial function in complex processes such as inflammatory response or tumor-induced angiogenesis. Most of these proteins are involved in processes in higher [[eukaryotes]], however an unconventional export mechanism was found in lower eukaryotes too.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nickel|first=W|title=Pathways of unconventional protein secretion.|journal=Current Opinion in Biotechnology|date=Oct 2010|volume=21|issue=5|pages=621–6|pmid=20637599|doi=10.1016/j.copbio.2010.06.004}}</ref> Even proteins folded in their correct conformation can pass plasma membrane this way, unlike proteins transported via [[Endoplasmic reticulum#Protein transport|ER/Golgi pathway]].<ref name="bla3"/> Two types of unconventional protein secretion are these: signal-peptid-containing proteins and cytoplasmatic and nuclear proteins that are missing an ER-signal peptide (1).<ref name="bla1">{{cite journal|last=Nickel|first=W|author2=Rabouille, C |title=Mechanisms of regulated unconventional protein secretion.|journal=Nature Reviews. Molecular Cell Biology|date=Feb 2009|volume=10|issue=2|pages=148–55|pmid=19122676|doi=10.1038/nrm2617}}</ref>
==Signal-peptide-containing proteins== These proteins contain a specific signal-peptide sequence, which is to be translated into the [[endoplasmic reticulum]], but are, however, able to reach the cell surface unconventionally. They can be packed into a COPII-coated vesicle and directly fuse with plasma membrane or can fuse with endosomal or lysosomal compartment. Alternatively, they can be packed into non-COPII-coated vesicle as well and fuse with Golgi (before reaching plasma membrane) or directly delivered to the plasma membrane.<ref name="bla1"/>
==Cytoplasmatic/nuclear secretory proteins== Soluble proteins can reach the surface of the cell both by non-vesicular and vesicular mechanisms. Non-vesicular mechanisms use a carrier to get proteins into extracellular space (for example phosphatidylinositol-4,5-bisphosphate). Vesicular mechanisms can use the [[lysosome-dependent pathway]], [[microvesicle shedding]] or biogenesis of [[multivesicular bodies]].<ref name="bla1"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Immunology]]

revision.text:
A '''bridged nucleic acid''' ('''BNA''') is a modified [[RNA]] nucleotide. They are sometimes also referred to as constrained or inaccessible RNA [[molecules]]. BNA [[monomers]] can contain a five-membered, six-membered or even a seven-membered bridged structure with a “fixed” C<sub>3</sub>’-endo sugar puckering.<ref>Saenger, W. (1984) ''Principles of Nucleic Acid Structure'', Springer-Verlag, New York, {{ISBN|3-540-90761-0}}.</ref> The bridge is synthetically incorporated at the 2’, 4’-position of the ribose to afford a 2’, 4’-BNA monomer. The monomers can be incorporated into [[oligonucleotide]] polymeric structures using standard phosphoamidite chemistry. BNAs are structurally rigid oligo-nucleotides with increased binding affinities and stability.
== Chemical structures == Chemical structures of BNA monomers containing a bridge at the 2’, 4’-position of the ribose to afford a 2’, 4’-BNA monomer as synthesized by Takeshi Imanishi’s group.<ref name=j1>{{Cite journal|last1=Obika|first1=S.|last2=Nanbu|first2=D.|last3=Hari|first3=Y.|last4=Morio|first4=K. I.|last5=In|first5=Y.|last6=Ishida|first6=T.|last7=Imanishi|first7=T.|doi=10.1016/S0040-4039(97)10322-7|title=Synthesis of 2′-O,4′-C-methyleneuridine and -cytidine. Novel bicyclic nucleosides having a fixed C3, -endo sugar puckering|journal=Tetrahedron Letters|volume=38|issue=50|pages=8735|year=1997|pmid=|pmc=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1039/b105640a|last1=Obika|first1=S.|last2=Onoda|first2=M.|last3=Andoh|first3=K.|last4=Imanishi|first4=J.|last5=Morita|first5=M.|last6=Koizumi|first6=T.|title=3'-amino-2',4'-BNA: Novel bridged nucleic acids having an N3'-->P5' phosphoramidate linkage|journal=Chemical Communications (Cambridge, England)|issue=19|pages=1992–1993|year=2001|pmid=12240255 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=A 2′,4′-Bridged Nucleic Acid Containing 2-Pyridone as a Nucleobase: Efficient Recognition of a C⋅G Interruption by Triplex Formation with a Pyrimidine Motif|doi=10.1002/1521-3773(20010601)40:11<2079::AID-ANIE2079>3.0.CO;2-Z|year=2001|last1=Obika|first1=Satoshi|last2=Hari|first2=Yoshiyuki|last3=Sekiguchi|first3=Mitsuaki|last4=Imanishi|first4=Takeshi|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|volume=40|issue=11|pages=2079}} </ref><ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1093/nass/1.1.241|last1=Morita|first1=K.|last2=Hasegawa|first2=C.|last3=Kaneko|first3=M.|last4=Tsutsumi|first4=S.|last5=Sone|first5=J.|last6=Ishikawa|first6=T.|last7=Imanishi|first7=T.|last8=Koizumi|first8=M.|title=2'-O,4'-C-ethylene-bridged nucleic acids (ENA) with nuclease-resistance and high affinity for RNA|journal=Nucleic Acids Research. Supplement|volume=1|issue=1|pages=241–242|year=2001|pmid=12836354 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Hari|first1=Y.|last2=Obika|first2=S.|last3=Sekiguchi|first3=M.|last4=Imanishi|first4=T.|title=Selective recognition of CG interruption by 2′,4′-BNA having 1-isoquinolone as a nucleobase in a pyrimidine motif triplex formation|doi=10.1016/S0040-4020(03)00728-2|journal=Tetrahedron|volume=59|issue=27|pages=5123|year=2003|pmid=|pmc=}}</ref><ref name="AbdurRahman">{{Cite journal|last1=Rahman|first1=S. M. A.|last2=Seki|first2=S.|last3=Obika|first3=S.|last4=Haitani|first4=S.|last5=Miyashita|first5=K.|last6=Imanishi|first6=T.|doi=10.1002/anie.200604857|title=Highly Stable Pyrimidine-Motif Triplex Formation at Physiological pH Values by a Bridged Nucleic Acid Analogue|journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition|volume=46|issue=23|pages=4306–4309|year=2007|pmid=17469090|pmc=}}</ref> The nature of the bridge can vary for different types of monomers. The 3D structures for A-RNA and B-DNA were used as a template for the design of the BNA monomers. The goal for the design was to find derivatives that possess high binding affinities with complementary RNA and/or DNA strands.
[[File:BNAH1.png|thumb|The 3D structures for A-RNA and B-DNA]]
[[File:BNAH2.png|thumb The presence of 2’-hydroxyls in the RNA backbone favors a structure that resembles the A-form structure of DNA. The flexible five-membered [[furanose]] ring in nucleotides exists in [[List of types of equilibrium|equilibrium]] of two preferred conformations of the N- (C<sub>3</sub>’-endo, A-form) and the S-type (C<sub>2</sub>’-endo, B-form) as illustrated in the next figure.]]
An increased conformational inflexibility of the sugar moiety in [[nucleosides]] (oligonucleotides) results in a gain of high binding affinity with complementary single-stranded RNA and/or double-stranded DNA. The first 2’,4’-BNA (LNA) monomers were first synthesized by Takeshi Imanishi’s group in 1997<ref name=j1/> followed independently by Jesper Wengel’s group in 1998.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Koshkin|first1=A. A.|last2=Singh|first2=S. K.|last3=Nielsen|first3=P.|last4=Rajwanshi|first4=V. K.|last5=Kumar|first5=R.|last6=Meldgaard|first6=M.|last7=Olsen|first7=C. E.|last8=Wengel|first8=J.|doi=10.1016/S0040-4020(98)00094-5|title=LNA (Locked Nucleic Acids): Synthesis of the adenine, cytosine, guanine, 5-methylcytosine, thymine and uracil bicyclonucleoside monomers, oligomerisation, and unprecedented nucleic acid recognition|journal=Tetrahedron|volume=54|issue=14|pages=3607|year=1998|pmid=|pmc=}}</ref>
[[File:BNAH6.png|thumb|Chemical structures of other BNAs that were synthesized in the past years as indicated below the structures.]]
BNA [[nucleotides]] can be incorporated into DNA or RNA [[oligonucleotides]] at any desired position. Such oligomers are synthesized chemically and are now commercially available. The bridged ribose conformation enhances base stacking and pre-organizes the backbone of the oligonucleotide significantly increasing their hybridization properties.
The incorporation of BNAs into oligonucleotides allows the production of modified synthetic oligonucleotides with equal or higher binding affinity against an DNA or RNA complement with excellent single-mismatch discriminating power; better RNA selective binding; stronger and more sequence selective triplex-forming characters; pronounced higher nuclease resistance, even higher than Sp-phosphorothioate analogues; and good aqueous [[solubility]] of the resulting oligonucleotides when compared to regular DNA or RNA oligonucleotides.
[[File:BNAH8.png|thumb| Chemical structures of BNAs were introduced in 2007 by Imanishi’s group.<ref name="AbdurRahman" /> These new generation of BNAs analogues are called 2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>[NH], 2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>[NMe], and 2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>[NBn].]]
New BNA analogs introduced by Imanishi’s group were designed by taking the length of the bridged [[moiety (chemistry)|moiety]] into account. A six-membered bridged structure with a unique structural feature (N-O bond) in the sugar moiety was designed to have a nitrogen atom. This atom improves the formation of duplexes and triplexes by lowering the repulsion between the negatively charged backbone phosphates. These modifications allow to control the affinity towards complementary strands, regulate resistance against nuclease degradation and the synthesis of functional molecules designed for specific applications in genomics. The properties of these analogs were investigated and compared to those of previous 2’,4’-BNA (LNA) modified oligonucleotides by Imanishi’s group. Imanishi’s results show that “2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>-modified oligonucleotides with these profiles show great promise for applications in antisense and antigene technologies.”
[[File:BNAH9.png|thumb|Makoto Koizumi in 2004 reviewed the properties of BNAs with focus on ENAs as antisense and antigen oligonucleotides (AONs) and proposed an action mechanism for these compounds that may involve translation arrest, mRNA degradation mediated by RNase H and splicing arrest.]]
==Proposed mechanism of action of AONs== Yamamoto et al. in 2012<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Koizumi|first1=M.|title=ENA oligonucleotides as therapeutics|journal=Current Opinion in Molecular Therapeutics|volume=8|issue=2|pages=144–149|year=2006|pmid=16610767 }}</ref> demonstrated that BNA-based antisense therapeutics inhibited hepatic PCSK9 expression, resulting in a strong reduction of the serum LDL-C levels of mice. The findings supported the hypothesis that PCSK9 is a potential therapeutic target for hypercholesterolemia and the researchers were able to show that BNA-based antisense oligonucleotides (AONs) induced cholesterol-lowering action in hypercholesterolemic mice. A moderate increase of aspartate aminotransferase, ALT, and blood urea nitrogen levels was observed whereas the histopathological analysis revealed no severe hepatic toxicities. The same group, also in 2012, reported that the 2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>[NMe] analog when used in antisense oligonucleotides showed significantly stronger inhibitory activities which is more pronounced in shorter (13- to 16mer) oligonucleotides. Their data led the researchers to conclude that the 2’,4’-BNA<sup>NC</sup>[NMe] analog may be a better alternative to conventional LNAs.
==Benefits of the BNA technology== Some of the benefits of BNAs include ideal for the detection of short RNA and DNA targets; increase the thermal stability of duplexes; capable of single nucleotide discrimination; increases the thermal stability of triplexes; resistance to exo- and enconucleases resulting in a high stability for ''in vivo'' and ''in vitro'' applications; increased target specificity; facilitate Tm normalization; strand invasion enables detection of “hard to access” samples; compatible with standard enzymatic processes.{{cn|date=January 2019}}
==Application of the BNA technology== Application of BNAs include small RNA research; design and synthesis of RNA aptamers; siRNA; antisense probes; diagnostics; isolation; microarray analysis; Northern blotting; real-time PCR; ''in situ'' hybridization; functional analysis; SNP detection and use as antigens and many others nucleotide base applications.{{cn|date=January 2019}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *https://web.archive.org/web/20130126055902/http://www.rockefeller.edu/labheads/tuschl/sirna.html *http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/software/ *{{cite book|last1=Pfundheller|first1=Henrik M.|title=Current Protocols in Nucleic Acid Chemistry|journal=Current Protocols in Nucleic Acid Chemistry|volume=Chapter 4|last2=Lomholt|first2=Christian|year=2002|pages=4.12.1–4.12.16|doi=10.1002/0471142700.nc0412s08|pmid=18428894|isbn=978-0471142706}}
[[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Nucleotides]]
