revision.text:
{{see also|Complement membrane attack complex}}
{{Pfam_box | Symbol = MACPF | Name = MAC/Perforin domain | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam= PF01823 | InterPro= IPR001862 | SMART= MACPF | PROSITE = PDOC00251 | SCOP = | TCDB = 1.C.39 | OPM family= 168 | OPM protein= 6h04 | PDB= | Membranome superfamily = 233 }}
The '''Membrane Attack Complex/Perforin (MACPF)''' [[Protein superfamily|superfamily]], sometimes referred to as the MACPF/CDC superfamily,<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Effects of MACPF/CDC proteins on lipid membranes|journal = Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences: CMLS|date = 2013-06-01|issn = 1420-9071|pmid = 22983385|pages = 2083–2098|volume = 70|issue = 12|doi = 10.1007/s00018-012-1153-8|first = Robert J. C.|last = Gilbert|first2 = Miha|last2 = Mikelj|first3 = Mauro|last3 = Dalla Serra|first4 = Christopher J.|last4 = Froelich|first5 = Gregor|last5 = Anderluh}}</ref> is named after a [[protein domain|domain]] that is common to the [[Complement membrane attack complex|membrane attack complex]] (MAC) proteins of [[Complement system|the complement system]] (C6, C7, C8α, C8β and [[Complement component 9|C9]]) and [[perforin]] (PF). Members of this [[protein family]] are [[pore forming toxins|pore-forming toxins (PFTs)]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Peitsch MC, Tschopp J |title=Assembly of macromolecular pores by immune defense systems |journal=Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=710–6 |year=1991 |pmid=1722985 |doi=10.1016/0955-0674(91)90045-Z}}</ref> In eukaryotes, MACPF proteins play a role in immunity and development.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = The MACPF/CDC family of pore-forming toxins|journal = Cellular Microbiology|date = 2008-09-01|issn = 1462-5822|pmc = 2654483|pmid = 18564372|pages = 1765–1774|volume = 10|issue = 9|doi = 10.1111/j.1462-5822.2008.01191.x|language = en|first = Carlos J.|last = Rosado|first2 = Stephanie|last2 = Kondos|first3 = Tara E.|last3 = Bull|first4 = Michael J.|last4 = Kuiper|first5 = Ruby H. P.|last5 = Law|first6 = Ashley M.|last6 = Buckle|first7 = Ilia|last7 = Voskoboinik|first8 = Phillip I.|last8 = Bird|first9 = Joseph A.|last9 = Trapani}}</ref>
Archetypal members of the family are [[Complement component 9|complement C9]] and [[perforin]], both of which function in human [[immunity (medical)|immunity]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tschopp J, Masson D, Stanley KK |title=Structural/functional similarity between proteins involved in complement- and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-mediated cytolysis |journal=Nature |volume=322 |issue=6082 |pages=831–4 |year=1986 |pmid=2427956 |doi=10.1038/322831a0}}</ref> C9 functions by punching holes in the membranes of [[Gram-negative]] bacteria. Perforin is released by [[cytotoxic T cells]] and [[lysis|lyse]]s virally infected and transformed cells. In addition, perforin permits delivery of cytotoxic proteases called [[granzyme]]s that cause [[cell death]].<ref name="Voskoboinik I, Smyth MJ, Trapani JA 2006 940–52">{{cite journal |vauthors=Voskoboinik I, Smyth MJ, Trapani JA |title=Perforin-mediated target-cell death and immune homeostasis |journal=Nat. Rev. Immunol. |volume=6 |issue=12 |pages=940–52 |year=2006 |pmid=17124515 |doi=10.1038/nri1983}}</ref> Deficiency of either protein can result in human disease.<ref name="fhl">{{cite journal |vauthors=Voskoboinik I, Sutton VR, Ciccone A, etal |title=Perforin activity and immune homeostasis: the common A91V polymorphism in perforin results in both presynaptic and postsynaptic defects in function |journal=Blood |volume=110 |issue=4 |pages=1184–90 |year=2007 |pmid=17475905 |doi=10.1182/blood-2007-02-072850}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Witzel-Schlömp K, Späth PJ, Hobart MJ, etal |title=The human complement C9 gene: identification of two mutations causing deficiency and revision of the gene structure |journal=J. Immunol. |volume=158 |issue=10 |pages=5043–9 |year=1997 |pmid=9144525 |doi=}}</ref> Structural studies reveal that MACPF domains are related to [[cholesterol-dependent cytolysin]]s (CDCs), a family of [[pore forming toxins]] previously thought to only exist in bacteria.<ref name="plumacpf">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rosado CJ, Buckle AM, Law RH, etal |title=A Common Fold Mediates Vertebrate Defense and Bacterial Attack |journal= Science|volume= 317|issue= 5844|pages= 1548–51|year=2007 |pmid=17717151 |doi=10.1126/science.1144706}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Structure of C8-MACPF Reveals Mechanism of Membrane Attack in Complement Immune Defense |author1=Michael A. Hadders |author2=Dennis X. Beringer |author3=Piet Gros |last-author-amp=yes |journal=Science |doi=10.1126/science.1147103 |pages=1552–1554 |year=2007 |volume=317 |pmid=17872444 |issue=5844}}</ref>
== Families == As of early 2016, there are three families belonging to the MACPF superfamily: * [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.12 1.C.12] - [[Cholesterol-dependent cytolysin|The Thiol-activated Cholesterol-dependent Cytolysin (CDC) Family]] * [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39 1.C.39] - The Membrane Attack Complex/Perforin (MACPF) Family * [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.97 1.C.97] - [[Pleurotolysin|The Pleurotolysin Pore-forming (Pleurotolysin) Family]]
=== Membrane Attack Complex/Perforin (MACPF) Family === Proteins containing MACPF domains play key roles in vertebrate immunity, embryonic development, and neural-cell migration.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Disparate proteins use similar architectures to damage membranes|journal = Trends in Biochemical Sciences|date = 2008-10-01|issn = 0968-0004|pmid = 18778941|pages = 482–490|volume = 33|issue = 10|doi = 10.1016/j.tibs.2008.07.004|first = Gregor|last = Anderluh|first2 = Jeremy H.|last2 = Lakey}}</ref> The ninth component of complement and perforin form oligomeric pores that lyse bacteria and kill virus-infected cells, respectively. The crystal structure of a bacterial MACPF protein, Plu-MACPF from ''Photorhabdus luminescens'' was determined ({{PDB|2QP2}}).<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A common fold mediates vertebrate defense and bacterial attack|journal = Science |date = 2007-09-14|issn = 1095-9203|pmid = 17717151|pages = 1548–1551|volume = 317|issue = 5844|doi = 10.1126/science.1144706|first = Carlos J.|last = Rosado|first2 = Ashley M.|last2 = Buckle|first3 = Ruby H. P.|last3 = Law|first4 = Rebecca E.|last4 = Butcher|first5 = Wan-Ting|last5 = Kan|first6 = Catherina H.|last6 = Bird|first7 = Kheng|last7 = Ung|first8 = Kylie A.|last8 = Browne|first9 = Katherine|last9 = Baran}}</ref> The MACPF domain is structurally similar to pore-forming [[cholesterol-dependent cytolysin]]s from [[gram-positive bacteria]], suggesting that MACPF proteins create pores and disrupt cell membranes similar to cytolysin. A representative list of proteins belonging to the MACPF family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39.9 Transporter Classification Database].
== Biological roles of MACPF domain containing proteins == Many proteins belonging to the MACPF superfamily play key roles in plant and animal immunity.
[[Complement system|Complement proteins]] C6-C9 all contain a MACPF domain and assemble into the membrane attack complex. C6, C7 and C8β appear to be non-lytic and function as scaffold proteins within the MAC. In contrast both C8α and C9 are capable of lysing cells. The final stage of MAC formation involves polymerisation of C9 into a large pore that punches a hole in the outer membrane of [[gram-negative bacteria]].
[[Perforin]] is stored in granules within cytotoxic T-cells and is responsible for killing virally infected and transformed cells. Perforin functions via two distinct mechanisms. Firstly, like C9, high concentrations of perforin can form pores that lyse cells. Secondly, perforin permits delivery of the cytotoxic granzymes A and B into target cells. Once delivered, granzymes are able to induce apoptosis and cause target cell death.<ref name="Voskoboinik I, Smyth MJ, Trapani JA 2006 940–52"/><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kaiserman D, Bird CH, Sun J, etal |title=The major human and mouse granzymes are structurally and functionally divergent |journal=J. Cell Biol. |volume=175 |issue=4 |pages=619–30 |year=2006 |pmid=17116752 |doi=10.1083/jcb.200606073 |pmc=2064598}}</ref>
The plant protein CAD1 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39.11.3 TC# 1.C.39.11.3]) functions in the plant immune response to bacterial infection.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Morita-Yamamuro C, Tsutsui T, Sato M, etal |title=The Arabidopsis gene CAD1 controls programmed cell death in the plant immune system and encodes a protein containing a MACPF domain |journal=Plant Cell Physiol. |volume=46 |issue=6 |pages=902–12 |year=2005 |pmid=15799997 |doi=10.1093/pcp/pci095}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Salicylic acid and a chitin elicitor both control expression of the CAD1 gene involved in the plant immunity of Arabidopsis|journal = Bioscience, Biotechnology, and Biochemistry|date = 2006-09-01|issn = 0916-8451|pmid = 16960394|pages = 2042–2048|volume = 70|issue = 9|doi = 10.1271/bbb.50700|first = Tomokazu|last = Tsutsui|first2 = Chizuko|last2 = Morita-Yamamuro|first3 = Yutaka|last3 = Asada|first4 = Eiichi|last4 = Minami|first5 = Naoto|last5 = Shibuya|first6 = Akira|last6 = Ikeda|first7 = Junji|last7 = Yamaguchi|hdl = 2115/14840}}</ref>
The [[sea anemone]] ''Actineria villosa'' uses a MACPF (AvTX-60A; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39.10.1 TC# 1.C.39.10.1])protein as a lethal toxin.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Oshiro N, Kobayashi C, Iwanaga S, etal |title=A new membrane-attack complex/perforin (MACPF) domain lethal toxin from the nematocyst venom of the Okinawan sea anemone Actineria villosa |journal=Toxicon |volume=43 |issue=2 |pages=225–8 |year=2004 |pmid=15019483 |doi=10.1016/j.toxicon.2003.11.017}}</ref>
MACPF proteins are also important for the invasion of the [[Malarial]] parasite into the mosquito host and the liver.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kadota K, Ishino T, Matsuyama T, Chinzei Y, Yuda M |title=Essential role of membrane-attack protein in malarial transmission to mosquito host |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=101 |issue=46 |pages=16310–5 |year=2004 |pmid=15520375 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0406187101 |pmc=524694}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ishino T, Chinzei Y, Yuda M |title=A Plasmodium sporozoite protein with a membrane attack complex domain is required for breaching the liver sinusoidal cell layer prior to hepatocyte infection |journal=Cell. Microbiol. |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=199–208 |year=2005 |pmid=15659064 |doi=10.1111/j.1462-5822.2004.00447.x}}</ref>
Not all MACPF proteins function in defence or attack. For example, [[astrotactin|astrotactin-1]] ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.87.3.1 TC# 9.B.87.3.1]) is involved in neural cell migration in mammals and apextrin ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39.7.4 TC# 1.C.39.7.4]) is involved in sea urchin (''[[Heliocidaris erythrogramma]]'') development.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Zheng C, Heintz N, Hatten ME |title=CNS gene encoding astrotactin, which supports neuronal migration along glial fibers |journal=Science |volume=272 |issue=5260 |pages=417–9 |year=1996 |pmid=8602532 |doi=10.1126/science.272.5260.417}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Haag ES, Sly BJ, Andrews ME, Raff RA |title=Apextrin, a novel extracellular protein associated with larval ectoderm evolution in Heliocidaris erythrogramma |journal=Dev. Biol. |volume=211 |issue=1 |pages=77–87 |year=1999 |pmid=10373306 |doi=10.1006/dbio.1999.9283}}</ref> ''[[Drosophila]]'' Torso-like protein ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.C.39.15.1 TC# 1.C.39.15.1]), which controls embryonic patterning,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Martin JR, Raibaud A, Ollo R |title=Terminal pattern elements in Drosophila embryo induced by the torso-like protein |journal=Nature |volume=367 |issue=6465 |pages=741–5 |year=1994 |pmid=8107870 |doi=10.1038/367741a0}}</ref> also contains a MACPF domain.<ref name="plumacpf" /> Its function is implicated in a receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway that specifies differentiation and terminal cell fate.
Functionally uncharacterised MACPF proteins are sporadically distributed in bacteria. Several species of ''Chlamydia'' contain MACPF proteins.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ponting CP |title=Chlamydial homologues of the MACPF (MAC/perforin) domain |journal=Curr. Biol. |volume=9 |issue=24 |pages=R911–3 |year=1999 |pmid=10608922 |doi=10.1016/S0960-9822(00)80102-5}}</ref> The insect pathogenic bacteria ''[[Photorhabdus luminescens]]'' also contains a MACPF protein, however, this molecule appears non-lytic.<ref name="plumacpf"/>
==Structure and mechanism== The X-ray crystal structure of Plu-MACPF, a protein from the [[insect]] pathogenic [[enterobacteria]] ''[[Photorhabdus luminescens]]'' has been determined (figure 1).[http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=2QP2] These data reveal that the MACPF domain is homologous to [[pore forming toxins|pore forming]] cholesterol dependent cytolysins (CDC's) from [[Gram positive|gram-positive]] pathogenic bacteria such as ''[[Clostridium perfringens]]'' (which causes [[gas gangrene]]). The [[amino acid]] sequence identity between the two families is extremely low, and the relationship is not detectable using conventional sequence based data mining techniques.<ref name="plumacpf"/>
It is suggested that MACPF proteins and CDCs form pores in the same way (figure 1).<ref name="plumacpf"/> Specifically it is hypothesised that MACPF proteins oligomerise to form a large circular pore (figure 2). A concerted conformational change within each monomer then results in two [[Alpha helix|α-helical]] regions unwinding to form four [[amphipathic]] [[Beta sheet|β-strands]] that span the [[Cell membrane|membrane]] of the target cell.<ref name="plumacpf"/> Like CDC's MACPF proteins are thus β-pore forming toxins that act like a molecular hole punch.
Other crystal structures for members of the MACPF superfamily can be found in RCSB: i.e., {{PDB2|3KK7}}, {{PDB2|3QOS}}, {{PDB2|3QQH}}, {{PDB2|3RD7}}, {{PDB2|3OJY}}
{| |+'''Mechanism of membrane attack by MACPF proteins''' |- | valign="top"| [[File:PFO and Plu-MACPF.png|thumb|left|400px|'''''Figure 1''': a) The structure of the CDC perfringolysin O <ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rossjohn J, Feil SC, McKinstry WJ, Tweten RK, Parker MW |title=Structure of a cholesterol-binding, thiol-activated cytolysin and a model of its membrane form |journal=Cell |volume=89 |issue=5 |pages=685–92 |year=1997 |pmid=9182756 |doi=10.1016/S0092-8674(00)80251-2}}</ref>[http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1PFO] and b) the structure of Plu-MACPF <ref name="plumacpf"/>[http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=2QP2]. In both proteins the two small clusters of [[Alpha helix|α-helicesl]] that are proposed to unwind and pierce the membrane are in pink.]] | valign="top"| [[Image:Molecular model of the pre-pore form of a MACPF protein based upon the structure of pneunolysin.png|thumb|right|335px|'''Figure 2:''' Molecular model of the pre-pore form of a MACPF protein based upon the structure of pneunolysin.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Tilley SJ, Orlova EV, Gilbert RJ, Andrew PW, Saibil HR |title=Structural basis of pore formation by the bacterial toxin pneumolysin |journal=Cell |volume=121 |issue=2 |pages=247–56 |year=2005 |pmid=15851031 |doi=10.1016/j.cell.2005.02.033}}</ref>]] |}
==Control of MACPF proteins== Complement regulatory proteins such as [[CD59]] function as [[membrane attack complex|MAC]] inhibitors and prevent inappropriate activity of complement against self cells (Figure 3). Biochemical studies have revealed the peptide sequences in C8α and C9 that bind to CD59.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Huang Y, Qiao F, Abagyan R, Hazard S, Tomlinson S |title=Defining the CD59-C9 binding interaction |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=281 |issue=37 |pages=27398–404 |year=2006 |pmid=16844690 |doi=10.1074/jbc.M603690200 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lockert DH, Kaufman KM, Chang CP, Hüsler T, Sodetz JM, Sims PJ |title=Identity of the segment of human complement C8 recognized by complement regulatory protein CD59 |journal=J. Biol. Chem. |volume=270 |issue=34 |pages=19723–8 |year=1995 |pmid=7544344 |doi=10.1074/jbc.270.8.3483}}</ref> Analysis of the MACPF domain structures reveals that these sequences map to the second cluster of helices that unfurl to span the membrane. It is therefore suggested that CD59 directly inhibits the MAC by interfering with conformational change in one of the membrane spanning regions.<ref name="plumacpf"/>
Other proteins that bind to the MAC include C8γ. This protein belongs to the [[lipocalin]] family and interacts with C8α. The binding site on C8α is known, however, the precise role of C8γ in the MAC remains to be understood.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Schreck SF, Plumb ME, Platteborze PL, etal |title=Expression and characterization of recombinant subunits of human complement component C8: further analysis of the function of C8 alpha and C8 gamma |journal=J. Immunol. |volume=161 |issue=1 |pages=311–8 |year=1998 |pmid=9647238 |doi=}}</ref><ref name="C8gamma">{{cite journal |vauthors=Lovelace LL, Chiswell B, Slade DJ, Sodetz JM, Lebioda L |title=Crystal structure of complement protein C8gamma in complex with a peptide containing the C8gamma binding site on C8alpha: Implications for C8gamma ligand binding |journal= Molecular Immunology|volume= 45|issue= 3|pages= 750–6|year=2007 |pmid=17692377 |doi=10.1016/j.molimm.2007.06.359}}</ref>
{| |+'''Proteins that bind MACPF domains''' |- | valign="top"| [[File:MAC inhibitor CD59.png|thumb|345px|'''Figure 3:''' NMR structure of [[CD59]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kieffer B, Driscoll PC, Campbell ID, Willis AC, van der Merwe PA, Davis SJ |title=Three-dimensional solution structure of the extracellular region of the complement regulatory protein CD59, a new cell-surface protein domain related to snake venom neurotoxins |journal=Biochemistry |volume=33 |issue=15 |pages=4471–82 |year=1994 |pmid=7512825 |doi=10.1021/bi00181a006}}</ref> [http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1ERG].]] | valign="top"| [[File:Crystal structure of C8gamma (green) with bound peptide from C8alpha (cyan).png|thumb|255px|'''Figure 3:''' Crystal structure of C8γ (green) with peptide from C8α (cyan).<ref name="C8gamma"/> [http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=2QOS].]] |}
==Role in human disease== Deficiency of C9, or other components of the MAC results in an increased susceptibility to diseases caused by [[Gram negative|gram-negative]] bacteria such as [[meningococcal]] [[meningitis]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kira R, Ihara K, Takada H, Gondo K, Hara T |title=Nonsense mutation in exon 4 of human complement C9 gene is the major cause of Japanese complement C9 deficiency |journal=Hum. Genet. |volume=102 |issue=6 |pages=605–10 |year=1998 |pmid=9703418 |doi=10.1007/s004390050749}}</ref> Overactivity of MACPF proteins can also cause disease. Most notably, deficiency of the MAC inhibitor CD59 results in an overactivity of complement and [[Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Walport |first=Mark J. |authorlink=Mark Walport|title=Complement. First of two parts |journal=N. Engl. J. Med. |volume=344 |issue=14 |pages=1058–66 |year=2001 |pmid=11287977 |doi=10.1056/NEJM200104053441406}}</ref>
[[Perforin]] deficiency results in the commonly fatal disorder [[HLH (Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis)|familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis]] (FHL or HLH).<ref name="fhl"/> This disease is characterised by an overactivation of [[lymphocytes]] which results in [[cytokine]] mediated organ damage.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Verbsky JW, Grossman WJ |title=Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis: diagnosis, pathophysiology, treatment, and future perspectives |journal=Ann. Med. |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=20–31 |year=2006 |pmid=16448985 |doi=10.1080/07853890500465189}}</ref>
The MACPF protein DBCCR1 may function as a tumor suppressor in [[bladder cancer]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wright KO, Messing EM, Reeder JE |title=DBCCR1 mediates death in cultured bladder tumor cells |journal=Oncogene |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=82–90 |year=2004 |pmid=14712213 |doi=10.1038/sj.onc.1206642}}</ref>
==Human proteins containing this domain == [[Complement component 6|C6]]; [[Complement component 7|C7]]; [[C8A]]; [[C8B]]; [[Complement component 9|C9]]; [[FAM5B]]; [[FAM5C]]; [[Macrophage expressed gene 1|MPEG1]]; [[PRF1]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Portal bar|Molecular and Cellular Biology|border=no}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}

revision.comment: Changed the order of images appearing on the page
revision.text:
'''Mitochondria''' are dynamic [[organelle]]s with the ability to fuse and divide ([[mitochondrial fission|fission]]), forming constantly changing tubular networks in most eukaryotic cells. These mitochondrial dynamics, first observed over a hundred years ago<ref name="Lewis 1915">{{cite journal|last1=Lewis|first1=Margaret|title=Mitochondria (and other cytoplamic structures) in tissue cultures |year=1915|url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/43100#page/349/mode/1up.full.pdf|journal=American Journal of Anatomy|volume= 17|number=3|pages=339-401|doi=10.1002/aja.1000170304}}</ref> are important for the health of the cell, and defects in dynamics lead to [[genetic disorder]]s. Through fusion, mitochondria can overcome the dangerous consequences of genetic malfunction.<ref name=Hales2010>{{cite journal|last1=Hales|first1=Karen G.|title=Mitochondrial Fusion and Division|journal=Nature Education|date=2010|volume=3|issue=9|page=12|url=http://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/mitochondrial-fusion-and-division-14264007|accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref> The process of mitochondrial fusion involves a variety of proteins that assist the cell throughout the series of events that form this process.
[[File:HeLa mtGFP.tif|thumb|Mitochondrial network (green) in two human cells ([[HeLa cells]])]] [[File:Mitochondria, mammalian lung - TEM (2).jpg|thumb|Mitochondria, mammalian lung - TEM (2)]]
==Process overview== When cells experience metabolic or environmental [[Stress (biology)|stresses]], mitochondrial fusion and [[mitochondrial fission|fission]] work to maintain functional mitochondria. An increase in fusion activity leads to mitochondrial elongation, whereas an increase in fission activity results in mitochondrial fragmentation.<ref name=Chan2006>{{cite journal | last1 = Chan | first1 = DC | year = 2006 | title = Mitochondrial fusion and fission in mammals | url = | journal = Annual Review of Cell and Developmental Biology | volume = 22| pages = 79–99 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.cellbio.22.010305.104638 | pmid = 16704336 }}</ref> The components of this process can influence [[programmed cell death]] and lead to [[neurodegenerative disorder]]s such as [[Parkinson's disease]]. Such cell death can be caused by disruptions in the process of either fusion or fission.<ref name=Youle2012>{{cite journal|last1=Youle|first1=Richard J.|title=Mitochondrial Fission, Fusion, and Stress|journal=Science Magazine|date=31 August 2012|volume=337| issue = 6098|pages=1062–1065|doi=10.1126/science.1219855|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/337/6098/1062.full#ref-1|accessdate=23 November 2014|pmid=22936770|pmc=4762028}}</ref>
The shapes of mitochondria in cells are continually changing via a combination of fission, fusion, and motility. Specifically, fusion assists in modifying stress by integrating the contents of slightly damaged mitochondria as a form of complementation. By enabling [[genetic complementation]], fusion of the mitochondria allows for two mitochondrial [[genome]]s with different defects within the same organelle to individually encode what the other lacks. In doing so, these mitochondrial genomes generate all of the necessary components for a functional mitochondrion.<ref name="Hales2010" />
==With mitochondrial fission==
The combined effects of continuous fusion and fission give rise to mitochondrial networks. The mechanisms of mitochondrial fusion and fission are regulated by [[proteolysis]] and posttranslational modifications. The actions of fission, fusion and motility cause the shapes of these double membrane bound subcellular organelles we know as mitochondria to continually alter their shapes.
The changes in balance between the rates of mitochondrial fission and fusion directly affect the wide range of mitochondrial lengths that can be observed in different cell types. Rapid fission and fusion of the mitochondria in cultured fibroblasts has been shown to promote the redistribution of mitochondrial [[green fluorescent protein]] (GFP) from one mitochondrion to all of the other mitochondria. This process can occur in a cell within a time period as short as an hour.<ref name="Youle2012" />
The significance of mitochondrial fission and fusion is distinct for nonproliferating neurons, which are unable to survive without mitochondrial fission. Such nonproliferating neurons cause two human diseases known as [[Kjer's optic neuropathy|dominant optic atrophy]] and [[Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease|Charcot Marie Tooth disease]] type 2A, which are both caused by fusion defects. Though the importance of these processes is evident, it is still unclear why mitochondrial fission and fusion are necessary for nonproliferating cells.
==Regulation==
Many gene products that control mitochondrial fusion have been identified, and can be reduced to three core groups which also control mitochondrial fission. These groups of proteins include mitofusins, [[OPA1]]/Mgm1, and Drp1/[[DNM1|Dnm1]]. All of these molecules are GTP hydrolyzing proteins ([[GTPases]]) that belong to the [[dynamin]] family. Mitochondrial dynamics in different cells are understood by the way in which these proteins regulate and bind to each other.<ref name=Hales2010/> These GTPases in control of mitochondrial fusion are well conserved between mammals, flies, and yeast. Mitochondrial fusion mediators differ between the outer and inner membranes of the mitochondria. Specific membrane-anchored dynamin family members mediate fusion between mitochondrial outer membranes known as [[MFN1|Mfn1]] and [[MFN2|Mfn2]]. These two proteins are mitofusin contained within humans that can alter the morphology of affected mitochondria in over-expressed conditions. However, a single dynamin family member known as OPA1 in mammals mediates fusion between mitochondrial inner membranes. These regulating proteins of mitochondrial fusion are organism-dependent; therefore, in ''Drosophila'' (fruit flies) and yeasts, the process is controlled by the mitochondrial transmembrane GTPase, Fzo. In ''Drosophila'', Fzo is found in postmeiotic spermatids and the dysfunction of this protein results in male sterility. However, a deletion of Fzo1 in budding yeast results in smaller, spherical mitochondria due to the lack of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).
==Apoptosis==
The balance between mitochondrial fusion and fission in cells is dictated by the up-and-down regulation of mitofusins, OPA1/Mgm1, and Drp1/Dnm1. [[Apoptosis]], or [[programmed cell death]], begins with the breakdown of mitochondria into smaller pieces. This process results from up-regulation of Drp1/Dnm1 and down-regulation of mitofusins. Later in the apoptosis cycle, an alteration of OPA1/Mgm1 activity within the inner mitochondrial membrane occurs. The role of the OPA1 protein is to protect cells against apoptosis by inhibiting the release of [[cytochrome c]]. Once this protein is altered, there is a change in the cristae structure, release of cytochrome c, and the activation of the destructive caspase enzymes. These resulting changes indicate that inner mitochondrial membrane structure is linked with regulatory pathways in influencing cell life and death. OPA1 plays both a genetic and molecular role in mitochondrial fusion and in cristae remodeling during apoptosis.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Frezza | first1 = C | last2 = Cipolat | first2 = S | last3 = Martins | first3 = | last4 = de Brito | first4 = O | last5 = Micaroni | first5 = M | last6 = Benznoussenko | first6 = GV | last7 = Rudka | first7 = T | last8 = Bartoli | first8 = D | last9 = Polishuck | first9 = RS | last10 = Danial | first10 = NN | last11 = De Strooper | first11 = B | last12 = Scorrano | first12 = L | year = 2006 | title = OPA1 controls apoptotic cristae remodeling independently from mitochondrial fusion | url = | journal = Cell | volume = 126 | issue = 1| pages = 177–189 | doi = 10.1016/j.cell.2006.06.025 | pmid = 16839885 }}</ref> OPA1 exists in two forms; the first being soluble and found in the intermembrane space, and the second as an integral inner membrane form, work together to restructure and shape the cristae during and after apoptosis. OPA1 blocks intramitochondrial cytochrome c redistribution which proceeds remodeling of the cristae. OPA1 functions to protect cells with mitochondrial dysfunction due to Mfn deficiencies, doubly for those lacking Mfn1 and Mfn2, but it plays a greater role in cells with only Mfn1 deficiencies as opposed to Mfn2 deficiencies. Therefore, it is supported that OPA1 function is dependent on the amount of Mfn1 present in the cell to promote mitochondrial elongation.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cipolat | first1 = S | last2 = Martins | first2 = | last3 = de Brito | first3 = O | last4 = Dal Zilio | first4 = B | last5 = Scorrano | first5 = L | year = 2004 | title = OPA1 requires mitofusin 1 to promote mitochondrial fusion | url = | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 101 | issue = 45| pages = 15927–15932 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0407043101 | pmid = 15509649 | pmc=528769}}</ref>
==In mammals==
Both proteins, Mfn1 and Mfn2, can act either together or separately during mitochondrial fusion. Mfn1 and Mfn2 are 81% similar to each other and about 51% similar to the ''Drosophila'' protein Fzo. Results published for a study to determine the impact of fusion on mitochondrial structure revealed that Mfn-deficient cells demonstrated either elongated cells (majority) or small, spherical cells upon observation.
The Mfn protein has three different methods of action: Mfn1 homotypic [[oligomer]]s, Mfn2 homotypic oligomers and Mfn1-Mfn2 heterotypic oligomers. It has been suggested that the type of cell determines the method of action but it has yet to be concluded whether or not Mfn1 and Mfn2 perform the same function in the process or if they are separate. Cells lacking this protein are subject to severe cellular defects such as poor cell growth, heterogeneity of mitochondrial membrane potential and decreased [[cellular respiration]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Chen | first1 = H | last2 = Chomyn | first2 = A | last3 = Chan | first3 = DC | year = 2005 | title = Disruption of fusion results in mitochondrial heterogeneity and dysfunction | url = | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 280 | issue = 28| pages = 26185–26192 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M503062200 | pmid = 15899901 }}</ref>
Mitochondrial fusion plays an important role in the process of [[Embryogenesis|embroygenesis]], as shown through the Mfn1 and Mfn2 proteins. Using Mfn1 and Mfn2 [[gene knockout|knock-out]] mice, which die in utero at midgestation due to a placental deficiency, mitochondrial fusion was shown not to be essential for cell survival in vitro, but necessary for embryonic development and cell survival throughout later stages of development. Mfn1 Mfn2 double knock-out mice, which die even earlier in development, were distinguished from the "single" knock-out mice. Mouse embryo fibroblasts (MEFs) originated from the double knock-out mice, which do survive in culture even though there is a complete absence of fusion, but parts of their mitochondria show a reduced mitochondrial DNA ([[Mitochondrial DNA|mtDNA]]) copy number and lose membrane potential. This series of events causes problems with [[adenosine triphosphate]] (ATP) synthesis.
== The Mitochondrial Inner/Outer Membrane Fusion (MMF) Family == The Mitochondrial Inner/Outer Membrane Fusion (MMF) Family ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.25 TC# 9.B.25]) is a family of proteins that play a role in mitochondrial fusion events. This family belongs to the larger [[Mitochondrial carrier|Mitochondrial Carrier (MC) Superfamily]]. The dynamic nature of mitochondria is critical for function. Chen and Chan (2010) have discussed the molecular basis of mitochondrial fusion, its protective role in neurodegeneration, and its importance in cellular function.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Physiological functions of mitochondrial fusion|journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|date = 2010-07-01|issn = 1749-6632|pmid = 20649534|pages = 21–25|volume = 1201|doi = 10.1111/j.1749-6632.2010.05615.x|first = Hsiuchen|last = Chen|first2 = David C.|last2 = Chan}}</ref> The mammalian mitofusins Mfn1 and Mfn2, GTPases localized to the outer membrane, mediate outer-membrane fusion. OPA1, a GTPase associated with the inner membrane, mediates subsequent inner-membrane fusion. Mutations in Mfn2 or OPA1 cause [[Neurodegeneration|neurodegenerative]] diseases. Mitochondrial fusion enables content mixing within a mitochondrial population, thereby preventing permanent loss of essential components. Cells with reduced mitochondrial fusion show a subpopulation of mitochondria that lack mtDNA nucleoids. Such mtDNA defects lead to respiration-deficient mitochondria, and their accumulation in neurons leads to impaired outgrowth of cellular processes and consequent neurodegeneration.
=== Family members === A representative list of the proteins belonging to the MMF family is available in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.25.2 Transporter Classification Database]. * [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.25.1.1 9.B.25.1.1] - The mitochondrial inner/outer membrane fusion complex, Fzo/Mgm1/Ugo1. Only the Ugo1 protein is a member of the MC superfamily. * [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.25.2.1 9.B.25.2.1] - The mammalian mitochondrial membrane fusion complex, Mitofusin 1 (Mfn1)/Mfn2/Optical Atrophy Protein 1 (OPA1) complex. This subfamily includes mitofusins 1 and 2.
=== Mitofusins: Mfn1 and Mfn2 === [[MFN1|Mfn1]] and [[MFN2|Mfn2]] ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=9.B.25.2.1 TC# 9.B.25.2.1]; [https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/Q8IWA4 Q8IWA4] and [https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/O95140 O95140], respectively), in mammalian cells are required for mitochondrial fusion, Mfn1 and Mfn2 possess functional distinctions. For instance, the formation of tethered structures ''in vitro'' occurs more readily when mitochondria are isolated from cells overexpressing Mfn1 than Mfn2.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mitofusin 1 and 2 play distinct roles in mitochondrial fusion reactions via GTPase activity|journal = Journal of Cell Science|date = 2004-12-15|issn = 0021-9533|pmid = 15572413|pages = 6535–6546|volume = 117|issue = Pt 26|doi = 10.1242/jcs.01565|first = Naotada|last = Ishihara|first2 = Yuka|last2 = Eura|first3 = Katsuyoshi|last3 = Mihara}}</ref> In addition, Mfn2 specifically has been shown to associate with Bax and Bak (Bcl-2 family, [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.a.21 TC#1.A.21]), resulting in altered Mfn2 activity, indicating that the mitofusins possess unique functional characteristics. Lipidic holes may open on opposing bilayers as intermediates, and fusion in cardiac [[myocyte]]s is coupled with outer mitochondrial membrane destabilization that is opportunistically employed during the mitochondrial permeability transition.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mitofusins and the mitochondrial permeability transition: the potential downside of mitochondrial fusion|journal = American Journal of Physiology. Heart and Circulatory Physiology|date = 2012-08-01|issn = 1522-1539|pmc = 3423162|pmid = 22636681|pages = H243–255|volume = 303|issue = 3|doi = 10.1152/ajpheart.00185.2012|first = Kyriakos N.|last = Papanicolaou|first2 = Matthew M.|last2 = Phillippo|first3 = Kenneth|last3 = Walsh}}</ref>
Mutations in Mfn2 (but not Mfn1) result in the neurological disorder [[Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease|Charcot-Marie-Tooth]] syndrome. These mutations can be complemented by the formation of Mfn1–Mfn2<sup>CMT2A</sup> hetero-oligomers but not homo-oligomers of Mfn2<sup>+</sup>–Mfn2<sup>CMT2A</sup><sub>.</sub><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Complementation between mouse Mfn1 and Mfn2 protects mitochondrial fusion defects caused by CMT2A disease mutations|journal = The Journal of Cell Biology|date = 2007-02-12|issn = 0021-9525|pmc = 2063976|pmid = 17296794|pages = 405–414|volume = 176|issue = 4|doi = 10.1083/jcb.200611080|first = Scott A.|last = Detmer|first2 = David C.|last2 = Chan}}</ref> This suggests that within the Mfn1–Mfn2 hetero-oligomeric complex, each molecule is functionally distinct. This suggests that control of the expression levels of each protein likely represents the most basic form of regulation to alter mitochondrial dynamics in mammalian tissues. Indeed, the expression levels of Mfn1 and Mfn2 vary according to cell or tissue type as does the mitochondrial morphology.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Two mitofusin proteins, mammalian homologues of FZO, with distinct functions are both required for mitochondrial fusion|journal = Journal of Biochemistry|date = 2003-09-01|issn = 0021-924X|pmid = 14561718|pages = 333–344|volume = 134|issue = 3|first = Yuka|last = Eura|first2 = Naotada|last2 = Ishihara|first3 = Sadaki|last3 = Yokota|first4 = Katsuyoshi|last4 = Mihara|doi=10.1093/jb/mvg150}}</ref>
=== Yeast mitochondrial fusion proteins === In yeast, three proteins are essential for mitochondrial fusion. Fzo1 ([https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/P38297 P38297]) and Mgm1 ([https://www.uniprot.org/uniprot/P32266 P32266]) are conserved guanosine triphosphatases that reside in the outer and inner membranes, respectively. At each membrane, these conserved proteins are required for the distinct steps of membrane tethering and lipid mixing. The third essential component is Ugo1, an outer membrane protein with a region homologous to but distantly related to a region in the Mitochondrial Carrier (MC) family. Hoppins ''et al.'', 2009 showed that Ugo1 is a modified member of this family, containing three transmembrane domains and existing as a dimer, a structure that is critical for the fusion function of Ugo1.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = The molecular mechanism of mitochondrial fusion|journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|date = 2009-01-01|issn = 0006-3002|pmid = 18691613|pages = 20–26|volume = 1793|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/j.bbamcr.2008.07.005|first = Suzanne|last = Hoppins|first2 = Jodi|last2 = Nunnari}}</ref> Their analyses of Ugo1 indicate that it is required for both outer and inner membrane fusion after membrane tethering, indicating that it operates at the lipid-mixing step of fusion. This role is distinct from the fusion dynamin-related proteins and thus demonstrates that at each membrane, a single fusion protein is not sufficient to drive the lipid-mixing step. Instead, this step requires a more complex assembly of proteins. The formation of a fusion pore has not yet been demonstrated.<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mitochondrial outer and inner membrane fusion requires a modified carrier protein|journal = The Journal of Cell Biology|date = 2009-02-23|issn = 1540-8140|pmc = 2654124|pmid = 19237599|pages = 569–581|volume = 184|issue = 4|doi = 10.1083/jcb.200809099|first = Suzanne|last = Hoppins|first2 = Jennifer|last2 = Horner|first3 = Cheng|last3 = Song|first4 = J. Michael|last4 = McCaffery|first5 = Jodi|last5 = Nunnari}}</ref> The Ugo1 protein is a member of the [[Mitochondrial carrier|MC superfamily]].
== See also == * [[Mitochondrial fission]] * [[Mitochondrial carrier]]s * [[MFN1]] * [[MFN2]] * [[OPA1]] * [[DNM1]] * [[Transporter Classification Database]]

revision.text:
The '''Nickel/Cobalt Transporter (NicO) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113 TC# 2.A.113]) is a member of the [[Lysine Exporter|Lysine Exporter (LysE) Superfamily]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tsu|first=Brian V.|last2=Saier|first2=Milton H.|date=2015-01-01|title=The LysE Superfamily of Transport Proteins Involved in Cell Physiology and Pathogenesis|journal=PLoS One|volume=10|issue=10|pages=e0137184|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0137184|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4608589|pmid=26474485}}</ref> A representative list of proteins belonging to the NicO family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113.2 Transporter Classification Database].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web | url = http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113 | title = The Nickel/cobalt Transporter (NicO) Family | website = Transporter Classification Database | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref>
== Homology == [[Homologous protein|Homologues]] of the NicO family have differing predicted topologies: 6, 7 and 8 TMSs. One such homologue, RcnA (YohM; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113.1.1 TC# 2.A.113.1.1]) of ''E. coli'' (274 aas) has 6 putative transmembrane segments (TMSs) in a 3 + 3 arrangement with a large hydrophilic loop between putativeTMSs 3 and 4.<ref name=":1" /> Several homologues of RcnA (e.g., RcnA homologue from ''[[Ralstonia solanacearum]]''; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113.1.3 TC# 2.A.113.1.3]; CAD17703) have 7 putative TMSs (4 + 3). Still another homologue, UreH of ''Methanocaldococcus janaschii'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.113.1.4 TC# 2.A.113.1.4]) has 6 putative TMSs in a more characteristic 3 + 3 TMS arrangement. The NicO family within the [[Lysine Exporter|LysE superfamily]] may have a common origin with the [[TOG Superfamily|TOG superfamily]], having lost TMSs 1 and 4 in the 8 TMS TOG superfamily topology.<ref name=":0" />
== Function == This protein is believed to catalyze Co<sup>2+</sup> and Ni<sup>2+</sup> efflux.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal | last = Rodrigue | first = Agnès | last2 = Effantin | first2 = Géraldine | last3 = Mandrand-Berthelot | first3 = Marie-Andrée | date = 2005-04-15 | title = Identification of rcnA (yohM), a Nickel and Cobalt Resistance Gene in Escherichia coli | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | language = en | volume = 187 | issue = 8 | pages = 2912–2916 | doi = 10.1128/JB.187.8.2912-2916.2005 | issn = 0021-9193 | pmc = 1070376 | pmid = 15805538 }}</ref>
The overall reaction catalyzed by proteins of the NicO family is probably:
[Ni<sup>2+</sup> or Co<sup>2+</sup>] (in) → [Ni<sup>2+</sup> or Co<sup>2+</sup>] (out).
== See also == * [[NiCoT family]], family of nickel/cobalt transporters within the TOG superfamily * [[Nickel]] * [[Cobalt]] * [[Transporter Classification Database]] * [[Transport protein]]

''Molecular Microbiology'' '''62''' (1): 252–262.[[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1111/j.1365-2958.2006.05369.x|10.1111/j.1365-2958.2006.05369.x]]. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17186148 "High-level resistance to cobalt and nickel but probably no transenvelope efflux: Metal resistance in the Cuban Serratia marcescens strain C-1"]. ''Microbial Ecology'' '''53''' (1): 123–133. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1007/s00248-006-9152-7|10.1007/s00248-006-9152-7]]. [[International Standard Serial Number|ISSN]] [https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0095-3628 0095-3628]. [[PubMed Identifier|PMID]] [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17186148 17186148]. * Protchenko, Olga; Rodriguez-Suarez, Roberto; Androphy, Rachel; Bussey, Howard; Philpott, Caroline C. (2006-07-28). [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16717099 "A screen for genes of heme uptake identifies the FLC family required for import of FAD into the endoplasmic reticulum"]. ''The Journal of Biological Chemistry'' '''281''' (30): 21445–21457.[[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1074/jbc.M512812200|10.1074/jbc.M512812200]]. [[International Standard Serial Number|ISSN]] [https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0021-9258 0021-9258].[[PubMed Identifier|PMID]] [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16717099 16717099].

{{DISPLAYTITLE:''p''-Aminobenzoyl-glutamate transporter}} {{Pfam_box | Symbol = AbgT | Name = | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam = PF03806 | Pfam_clan = | InterPro = | SMART = | PROSITE = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.68 | OPM family = 272 | OPM protein = 4r1i | PDB = }} The '''''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate transporter''' '''(AbgT) family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68 TC# 2.A.68]) is a family of transporter proteins belonging to the [[Ion transporter|ion transporter (IT) superfamily]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Prakash S, Cooper G, Singhi S, Saier MH | title = The ion transporter superfamily | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1618 | issue = 1 | pages = 79–92 | date = December 2003 | pmid = 14643936 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Rabus R, Jack DL, Kelly DJ, Saier MH | title = TRAP transporters: an ancient family of extracytoplasmic solute-receptor-dependent secondary active transporters | journal = Microbiology | volume = 145 ( Pt 12) | issue = 12 | pages = 3431–45 | date = December 1999 | pmid = 10627041 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-145-12-3431 }} The AbgT family consists of the AbgT (YdaH; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68.1.1 TC# 2.A.68.1.1]) protein of ''E. coli'' and the MtrF drug exporter ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68.1.2 TC# 2.A.68.1.2]) of ''[[Neisseria gonorrhoeae]]''.{{cite journal | vauthors = Hussein MJ, Green JM, Nichols BP | title = Characterization of mutations that allow p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate utilization by Escherichia coli | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 180 | issue = 23 | pages = 6260–8 | date = December 1998 | pmid = 9829935 | pmc = 107711 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Folster JP, Shafer WM | title = Regulation of mtrF expression in Neisseria gonorrhoeae and its role in high-level antimicrobial resistance | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 187 | issue = 11 | pages = 3713–20 | date = June 2005 | pmid = 15901695 | pmc = 1112036 | doi = 10.1128/JB.187.11.3713-3720.2005 }} The former protein is apparently cryptic in wild-type cells, but when expressed on a high copy number plasmid, or when expressed at higher levels due to mutation, it appeared to allow uptake (''K''m = 123 nM; see [[Michaelis–Menten kinetics]]) and subsequent utilization of ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate as a source of [[P aminobenzoate|''p''-aminobenzoate]] for ''p''-aminobenzoate [[Auxotrophy|auxotrophs]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Carter EL, Jager L, Gardner L, Hall CC, Willis S, Green JM | title = Escherichia coli abg genes enable uptake and cleavage of the folate catabolite p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 189 | issue = 9 | pages = 3329–34 | date = May 2007 | pmid = 17307853 | pmc = 1855889 | doi = 10.1128/JB.01940-06 }} ''p''-Aminobenzoate is a constituent of and a precursor for the biosynthesis of [[folic acid]]. MtrF was annotated as a putative [[Efflux (microbiology)|drug efflux pump]]. == Structure == AbgT is 510 amino acyl residues long and has 12-13 putative transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). MtrF is 522 aas long and has 11 or 12 putative TMSs. The 3-d structures of MtrF and a YdaH homologue have been solved, and functional studies show that it is a drug exporter. The 3-d structure shows that it has 9 TMSs with hairpin entry loops.{{cite journal | vauthors = Su CC, Bolla JR, Kumar N, Radhakrishnan A, Long F, Delmar JA, Chou TH, Rajashankar KR, Shafer WM, Yu EW | title = Structure and function of Neisseria gonorrhoeae MtrF illuminates a class of antimetabolite efflux pumps | journal = Cell Reports | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 61–70 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25818299 | pmc = 4410016 | doi = 10.1016/j.celrep.2015.03.003 }} Crystal Structures: == Genetics == The ''abgT'' gene is preceded by two genes, ''abgA'' and ''abgB,'' which code for homologous amino acyl amino hydrolases and hydrolyze ''p''-aminobenzoyl glutamate to ''p''-aminobenzoate and glutamate. Because of the structural similarity of ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutatmate to peptides, and the enzymatic activities of the ''abgA'' and ''abgB'' gene products, it has been suggested that AbgT is also a peptide transporter. Demonstration of an energy requirement suggested an H+-dependent mechanism. Expression of these genes is regulated by AbgR and an unknown effector. == Function == As noted above, the AbgT family of transporters has been thought to contribute to bacterial [[Folic acid|folate biosynthesis]] by importing the catabolite ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate for producing folate. Approximately 13,000 putative family members were identified in 2015.{{cite journal | vauthors = Delmar JA, Yu EW | title = The AbgT family: A novel class of antimetabolite transporters | journal = Protein Science | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages = 322–37 | date = February 2016 | pmid = 26443496 | pmc = 4815354 | doi = 10.1002/pro.2820 }} The X-ray structures of the full-length ''[[Alcanivorax borkumensis]]'' YdaH (AbgT) and ''[[Neisseria gonorrhoeae]]'' MtrF proteins. The structures revealed that these two transporters assemble as dimers with architectures distinct from all other families of transporters for which 3-d structures were available.{{cite journal | vauthors = Bolla JR, Su CC, Delmar JA, Radhakrishnan A, Kumar N, Chou TH, Long F, Rajashankar KR, Yu EW | title = Crystal structure of the Alcanivorax borkumensis YdaH transporter reveals an unusual topology | journal = Nature Communications | volume = 6 | pages = 6874 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25892120 | pmc = 4410182 | doi = 10.1038/ncomms7874 }} Both YdaH and MtrF are bowl-shaped dimers with a solvent-filled basin extending from the cytoplasm halfway across the [[Lipid bilayer|membrane bilayer]]. The protomers of YdaH and MtrF contain nine transmembrane helices and two hairpins which suggested a plausible pathway for substrate transport. A combination of the crystal structure, genetic analyses and substrate accumulation assays indicated that both YdaH and MtrF behave as exporters, capable of removing the folate metabolite ''p''-aminobenzoic acid from bacterial cells. In fact, it was shown that both YdaH and MtrF participate as [[Antibiotics|antibiotic]] efflux pumps, mediating bacterial resistance to [[Sulfonamide (medicine)|sulfonamide antimetabolite drugs]]. Possibly, many AbgT-family transporters act as exporters, conferring resistance to [[Sulfadiazine|sulfonamides]]. === Transport reaction === The generalized transport reaction initially proposed for AbgT is:
''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate (out) + nH+ (out) → ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate (in) + nH+ (in)
but the more recently proposed transport reaction is:
Sulfonamide drugs (in) + H+ (out) → Sulfonamide drugs (out) + H+ (in)

revision.text:
The '''Citrate-Mg<sup>2+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> (CitM) / Citrate-Ca<sup>2+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> (CitH) Symporter (CitMHS) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.11 TC# 2.A.11]) is a family of transport proteins belonging to the [[Ion transporter superfamily]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}}</ref> Members of this family are found in [[Gram-positive bacteria|Gram-positive]] and [[Gram-negative bacteria]], archaea and possibly eukaryotes. These proteins all probably arose by an internal [[gene duplication]] event. Lensbouer & Doyle (2010) have reviewed these systems, classifying the porters with three superfamilies, according to ion-preference:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lensbouer|first=Joshua J.|last2=Patel|first2=Ami|last3=Sirianni|first3=Joseph P.|last4=Doyle|first4=Robert P.|date=2008-08-01|title=Functional characterization and metal ion specificity of the metal-citrate complex transporter from Streptomyces coelicolor|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=190|issue=16|pages=5616–5623|doi=10.1128/JB.00456-08|issn=1098-5530|pmc=2519374|pmid=18556792}}</ref>
1) Mg<sup>2+</sup>-preferring,
2) Ca<sup>2+</sup>-preferring, and
3) Fe<sup>2+</sup>-preferring.
A representative list of proteins belonging to the CitMHS family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.2 Transporter Classification Database].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.11|title=2.A.11. The Citrate-Mg2+:H+ (CitM) Citrate-Ca2+:H+ (CitH) Symporter (CitMHS) Family|website=Transporter Classification Database|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref>
== CitM and CitH == Two of the characterized members of the CitMHS family, both [[Citric acid|citrate]] uptake permeases from ''[[Bacillus subtilis]]'', are CitM ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.1.1 TC# 2.A.11.1.1]) and CitH ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.1.2 TC# 2.A.11.1.2])''.''
=== Function === CitM is believed to transport a citrate<sup>2−</sup>-Mg<sup>2+</sup>complex in [[Symporter|symport]] with one H<sup>+</sup> per Mg<sup>2+</sup>-citrate while CitH apparently transports a citrate<sup>2−</sup>-Ca<sup>2+</sup> complex in symport with protons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boorsma|first=A.|last2=van der Rest|first2=M. E.|last3=Lolkema|first3=J. S.|last4=Konings|first4=W. N.|date=1996-11-01|title=Secondary transporters for citrate and the Mg(2+)-citrate complex in Bacillus subtilis are homologous proteins|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=178|issue=21|pages=6216–6222|issn=0021-9193|pmc=178492|pmid=8892821|doi=10.1128/jb.178.21.6216-6222.1996}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Krom|first=B. P.|last2=Warner|first2=J. B.|last3=Konings|first3=W. N.|last4=Lolkema|first4=J. S.|date=2000-11-01|title=Complementary metal ion specificity of the metal-citrate transporters CitM and CitH of Bacillus subtilis|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=182|issue=22|pages=6374–6381|issn=0021-9193|pmc=94783|pmid=11053381|doi=10.1128/jb.182.22.6374-6381.2000}}</ref> The cation specificity of CitM is: [[Magnesium|Mg<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Manganese|Mn<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Barium|Ba<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Nickel|Ni<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Cobalt|Co<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Calcium in biology|Ca<sup>2+</sup>]] and [[Zinc|Zn<sup>2+</sup>]], in this preferential order. CitM is highly specific for citrate and D-isocitrate and does not transport other di- and tri-carboxylates including succinate, L-isocitrate, cis-aconitate and tricarballylate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=H.|last2=Pajor|first2=A. M.|date=2002-01-01|title=Functional characterization of CitM, the Mg2+-citrate transporter|journal=The Journal of Membrane Biology|volume=185|issue=1|pages=9–16|doi=10.1007/s00232-001-0106-1|issn=0022-2631|pmid=11891560}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warner|first=Jessica B.|last2=Lolkema|first2=Juke S.|date=2002-11-01|title=Growth of Bacillus subtilis on citrate and isocitrate is supported by the Mg2+-citrate transporter CitM|journal=Microbiology|volume=148|issue=Pt 11|pages=3405–3412|doi=10.1099/00221287-148-11-3405|issn=1350-0872|pmid=12427932}}</ref> For CitH, the cation specificity (in order of preference) is: Ca<sup>2+</sup>, Ba<sup>2+</sup> and [[Strontium|Sr<sup>2+</sup>]].<ref name=":0" /> The two proteins are 60% identical, contain about 400 amino acyl residues and possess twelve putative transmembrane spanners. A CitM homologue in ''[[Streptococcus mutans|S. mutans]]'' transports citrate conjugated to [[Ferrous|Fe<sup>2+</sup>]] or Mn<sup>2+</sup> but not Ca<sup>2+</sup>, Mg<sup>2+</sup> or Ni<sup>2+</sup>.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Korithoski|first=Bryan|last2=Krastel|first2=Kirsten|last3=Cvitkovitch|first3=Dennis G.|date=2005-07-01|title=Transport and metabolism of citrate by Streptococcus mutans|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=187|issue=13|pages=4451–4456|doi=10.1128/JB.187.13.4451-4456.2005|issn=0021-9193|pmc=1151779|pmid=15968054}}</ref>
The transport reactions catalyzed by (1) CitM and (2) CitH, respectively, are:
(1) Citrate • Mg (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate • Mg (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
(2) Citrate (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
(3) Citrate • Ca<sup>2+</sup> (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate • Ca<sup>2+</sup> (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
== See also == * [[Membrane transport protein]] * [[Carrier protein]] * [[Calcium in biology]] * [[Transporter Classification Database]]

revision.text:
The '''NhaB family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.34 TC# 2.A.34]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaB family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.34.1 Transporter Classification Database]. NhaB homologues are usually about 500 amino acyl residues (aas) in length and possess about 12 transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs), although some members differ in their number of TMSs. NhaB homologues also exhibit a region with limited sequence similarity to a 46 kDa membrane protein of unknown function from ''[[Mycobacterium leprae]]'' (spP46838) which is also homologous to a member of arsenate resistance pumps of bacteria, archaea and eukaryotes ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.a.4 TC# 3.A.4]). Only [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] bacterial proteins have been functionally characterized. The ''E. coli'' NhaB is 58% identical to the orthologous ''[[Vibrio alginolyticus]]'' Na+/H+ antiporter.{{Cite journal|last=Pinner|first=E.|last2=Padan|first2=E.|last3=Schuldiner|first3=S.|date=1992-06-05|title=Cloning, sequencing, and expression of the nhaB gene, encoding a Na+/H+ antiporter in Escherichia coli|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=267|issue=16|pages=11064–11068|issn=0021-9258|pmid=1317851}} Although the latter protein is predicted to exhibit 10 TMSs, construction of ''NhaB-phoA'' fusions led to evidence for a 9 TMS model with the N-terminus in the cytoplasm and the C-terminus in the [[periplasm]].{{Cite journal|last=Enomoto|first=H.|last2=Unemoto|first2=T.|last3=Nishibuchi|first3=M.|last4=Padan|first4=E.|last5=Nakamura|first5=T.|date=1998-03-06|title=Topological study of Vibrio alginolyticus NhaB Na+/H+ antiporter using gene fusions in Escherichia coli cells|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1370|issue=1|pages=77–86|issn=0006-3002|pmid=9518558|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(97)00245-9}} A centrally located aspartyl residue in the 3rd TMS is conserved in all members of the family and important for activity.{{Cite journal|last=Nakamura|first=T.|last2=Fujisaki|first2=Y.|last3=Enomoto|first3=H.|last4=Nakayama|first4=Y.|last5=Takabe|first5=T.|last6=Yamaguchi|first6=N.|last7=Uozumi|first7=N.|date=2001-10-01|title=Residue aspartate-147 from the third transmembrane region of Na(+)/H(+) antiporter NhaB of Vibrio alginolyticus plays a role in its activity|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=183|issue=19|pages=5762–5767|doi=10.1128/JB.183.19.5762-5767.2001|issn=0021-9193|pmc=95471|pmid=11544242}} The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by NhaB of ''E. coli'' is:
2 Na+ (in) + 3 H+ (out) ⇌ 2 Na+ (out) + 3 H+ (in).
== See also == * [[Sodium-Proton antiporter]] * [[Antiporter]] * [[Transporter Classification Database]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Portal bar|Molecular and Cellular Biology|border=no}} {{CCBYSASource|sourcepath=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.34|sourcearticle=2.A.34 The NhaB Na+:H+ Antiporter (NhaB) Family|revision=699838558}} [[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Protein families]] [[Category:Membrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane transporters]] [[Category:Transport proteins]] [[Category:Integral membrane proteins]] {{membrane-protein-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Further reading */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: FEMS microbiology letters → FEMS Microbiology Letters (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''NhaC family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35 TC# 2.A.35]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaC family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35.3 Transporter Classification Database]. Two members of the NhaC family have been functionally characterized. One is believed to be a Na+:H+ antiporter;{{Cite journal|last=Ito|first=M.|last2=Guffanti|first2=A. A.|last3=Zemsky|first3=J.|last4=Ivey|first4=D. M.|last5=Krulwich|first5=T. A.|date=1997-06-01|title=Role of the nhaC-encoded Na+/H+ antiporter of alkaliphilic Bacillus firmus OF4|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=179|issue=12|pages=3851–3857|issn=0021-9193|pmc=179192|pmid=9190799}} the other is a malate·H+:lactate·Na+ antiporter.{{Cite journal|last=Wei|first=Y.|last2=Guffanti|first2=A. A.|last3=Ito|first3=M.|last4=Krulwich|first4=T. A.|date=2000-09-29|title=Bacillus subtilis YqkI is a novel malic/Na+-lactate antiporter that enhances growth on malate at low protonmotive force|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=275|issue=39|pages=30287–30292|doi=10.1074/jbc.M001112200|issn=0021-9258|pmid=10903309}} Several paralogues are found in ''[[Vibrio cholerae]],'' and two paralogues are found encoded in the completely sequenced genomes of both''[[Haemophilus influenzae]]'' and ''[[Bacillus subtilis]].'' ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]'' lacks such a homologue. ''[[Pyrococcus]]'' species also have at least one homologue each. Thus, members of the NhaC family are found in both [[Gram-negative bacteria]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]] as well as archaea. NhaC of ''B. firmus'' is 462 amino acyl residues long and possesses 12 putative transmembrane α-helical segments. MleN of ''B. subtilis'' (468 aas; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35.1.2 TC# 2.A.35.1.2]) also exhibits 12 putative TMSs. The transport reaction catalyzed by NhaC is probably:
Na+ (in) + nH+ (out) ⇌ Na+ (out) + nH+ (in). (n > 1)
That catalyzed by MleN is probably:
Malate (out) + H+ (out) + Lactate (in) + Na+ (in) ⇌ Malate (in) + H+ (in) + Lactate (out) + Na+ (out)

G1 in Escherichia coli"]. ''FEMS Microbiology Letters'' '''276''' (1): 114–122. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1111/j.1574-6968.2007.00925.x|10.1111/j.1574-6968.2007.00925.x]]. (2011-07-01).[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21531804 "Inference of the transcriptional regulatory network in Staphylococcus aureus by integration of experimental and genomics-based evidence"]. [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[[doi:10.1128/JB.01208-08|10.1128/JB.01208-08]].[[International Standard Serial Number|ISSN]] [https://www.worldcat.org/issn/1098-5530 1098-5530]. The '''NhaD family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.62 TC# 2.A.62]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaD family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.62.1 Transporter Classification Database]. The NhaD Na+/H+ antiporter has been characterized from two ''Vibrio'' species: ''[[Vibrio parahaemolyticus|V. parahaemolyticus]]'' and ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' and in the haloalkaliphile, ''[[Alkalimonas amylolytica]]''.{{Cite journal|last=Nozaki|first=K.|last2=Kuroda|first2=T.|last3=Mizushima|first3=T.|last4=Tsuchiya|first4=T.|date=1998-03-02|title=A new Na+/H+ antiporter, NhaD, of Vibrio parahaemolyticus|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1369|issue=2|pages=213–220|issn=0006-3002|pmid=9518619|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(97)00223-x}}{{Cite journal|last=Ostroumov|first=Elena|last2=Dzioba|first2=Judith|last3=Loewen|first3=Peter C.|last4=Dibrov|first4=Pavel|date=2002-08-19|title=Asp(344) and Thr(345) are critical for cation exchange mediated by NhaD, Na(+)/H(+) antiporter of Vibrio cholerae|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1564|issue=1|pages=99–106|issn=0006-3002|pmid=12101001|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(02)00407-8}} These proteins and their homologues are 400-500 aas long and exhibit 10-13 TMSs. They catalyze Na+/H+ and Li+/H+ antiport. They exhibit activity at basic pH (8-10) with no activity at pH 7.5. The ''Amylolytica'' antiporter has low Na+ affinity and has optimal activity at 600 mM Na+. Homologues are found in proteobacteria of all groups, ''[[Flavobacteriia|Flavobacteria]]'' and ''[[Chlamydiae|Chlamydia]].'' Distant homologues of the [[Ion transporter|IT superfamily]] are ubiquitous. The generalized reaction catalyzed by NhaD is:
nH+ (in) + mNa+ (out) ⇌ nH+ (out) + mNa+ (in).
